content:
Orchitis: Causes, signs, diagnosis and prevention

Orchitis is a urinary disease that causes swelling and pain in the patient's testicles. The most common is unilateral orchitis. Orchitis can be caused by infection or by the development of mumps and epididymitis. Patients will have their quality of life affected due to the symptoms the disease brings. More dangerously, prolonged orchitis will reduce fertility in patients.

What is orchitis?
Orchitis is a condition in which a person's testicles are inflamed on one or both sides. The most common is unilateral orchitis caused by a urinary tract infection. The disease can be transmitted from person to person through blood. Therefore, people who have unsafe sex are more likely to get orchitis than other groups of people. (first)
Testicles are an organ located in the male gonads, whose main role is to produce sperm and secrete testosterone, the male sex hormone. The testicles are covered by  a thin bag of skin, called the scrotum, underneath and behind the penis. The testicles function under the influence of the testicular plexus, which contains nerves from the renal plexus and the aorta.
The average size of a normal testicle is 4 - 5.1cm. In case the testicles are larger than 5.1cm, it means that the person is likely to suffer from diseases related to the testicles, including orchitis.
Common orchitis is orchitis caused by urinary infection, and some cases are caused by epididymitis that spreads bacteria to the testicles. The disease occurs most often in young, sexually active men because this is the factor that makes men most susceptible to urinary tract infections.
There are two types of orchitis: acute and chronic. For acute orchitis, although the disease can cause pain and inconvenient symptoms, it can be completely treated with simple internal medicine methods, using oral medication.
However, patients should not be subjective about orchitis. In case the patient does not treat the disease or treats orchitis incorrectly, the disease will gradually develop into chronic orchitis. The disease poses countless risks of other urinary complications, directly affecting the patient's health and fertility.

Cause of orchitis
The causes of orchitis are very diverse, but the most common are urinary tract infections, the consequences of mumps and unprotected sex.
1. Mumps & autoimmune diseases
Orchitis is mostly caused by bacteria. Among them, mumps bacteria, belonging to the Paramyxoviridae family that causes mumps, is the most common bacteria that causes orchitis. (2)
The rate of men getting orchitis after 4-7 days of mumps is quite high, for every 3 people with mumps, 1 person will have orchitis afterward. This means that subjects including post-pubescent children and people who are not vaccinated against mumps are more likely to get orchitis than others.
See more: Common symptoms of orchitis caused by mumps
In addition, other autoimmune diseases can also cause orchitis in men including:
Chicken pot; Cytomegalovirus infection, cytomegalovirus infection; HFMD
2. Sexually transmitted diseases STDs & unsafe sexual activities
Orchitis caused by STDs and sexually transmitted diseases is also a common cause in cases.
First, orchitis is a disease that can be transmitted from person to person by blood. Unsafe sex carries a high risk of transmitting viruses through blood. Therefore, in case of unprotected sex with someone who has orchitis, you will also have a high chance of getting orchitis.
In addition, other sexually transmitted STDs also lead to orchitis. The explanation is because the testicles are the closest organs and are directly in contact with bacteria that cause disease in humans. Therefore, when men have STDs, they need to pay attention to their risk of orchitis.
Sexually transmitted diseases that can cause orchitis include:
Gonorrhea; Syphilis; Epididymitis
3. Urinary tract infection
Orchitis can be a consequence of other urinary tract infections. In particular, infections that are not treated early will increase the risk of orchitis in patients, because then disease-causing bacteria will develop and spread to other nearby parts and organs.
Urinary tract infections that can lead to orchitis include:
Infection with E.coli, staphylococcus and streptococcus bacteria; Prostatitis; Infections caused by placing catheters or medical instruments in the penis

Symptoms and signs of orchitis
Typical orchitis symptoms are pain in the testicles and groin area. Usually, testicular pain will start with one testicle and gradually spread to the other testicle. Groin pain and testicular pain are relatively similar, so patients may mistake orchitis for diseases that cause pain in areas other than the groin.
When unusual pain occurs in the groin, it is necessary to observe the health condition of the body, especially the scrotal skin in the testicles. If the patient also has pain in the scrotum, it is a clinical sign of damage to the testicles.
Common symptoms of orchitis that men can recognize:
Scrotal pain; Pain in one or both testicles; The testicles are swollen on one or both sides; Swollen scrotum; painful urination; Pain during ejaculation; Semen mixed with blood; Swollen lymph nodes in the groin area; Some cases have symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, fatigue, fever & chills, and muscle pain

Risk of orchitis
1. Subject
Orchitis can happen to anyone of any age. However, the disease often occurs in 3 main groups of people including: (3)
Boys from 10 to 19 years old: At this age, boys have a high risk of getting mumps. This leads to an increased risk of orchitis in children; Men who are sexually active: This is an activity that increases the risk of transmitting infections, including orchitis; Men over 45 years old
2. Risk factors increase the risk of disease
People at high risk of orchitis are  people who are suffering from mumps. Boys aged 10 - 19 years old and those who have not been vaccinated against mumps have a high chance of contracting mumps and developing orchitis.
On the other hand, orchitis is also a disease caused by infection. Therefore, people whose activities are prone to urinary tract infections are also at high risk of orchitis.
Activities and factors that increase the likelihood of orchitis in men include:
Having sex without using protection; Have a history of sexually transmitted diseases STDs; People who have had or are inserting catheters or other medical devices into the penis; People with congenital diseases of the urinary system, usually the bladder or urethra structures

Is orchitis dangerous?
Orchitis rarely affects fertility in patients. Furthermore, orchitis, if treated early and properly, can be completely cured.
However, patients need to pay attention to treatment as soon as any symptoms appear. Although orchitis does not affect the patient's urinary system health, orchitis also causes certain inconveniences in the patient's daily activities.
Pain in the testicles, groin area and scrotal skin are the main causes of discomfort, and more seriously, lead to stress and decreased mental health in the patient. In addition, if orchitis persists or recurs many times, it will cause the infection to spread. Pathogenic bacteria will spread to nearby organs and cause infection. This leads to other complications such as:
Abscess in the scrotum; Accumulation of fluid in the scrotum; Testicular atrophy; Chronic orchitis; Sepsis

When to see a doctor?
Patients with orchitis need to see a doctor for an in-depth examination and a treatment regimen for orchitis as soon as they detect or have suspected symptoms of the disease.
The possibility of completely treating orchitis will be higher if the disease is treated in its early stages. Another benefit when a patient sees a doctor early is to minimize the risk of the disease developing into other complications, which can directly and more seriously affect the patient's quality of life as well as  overall health. patient.
In particular, people with orchitis who have symptoms such as intense testicular pain and painful urination need to see a urologist for timely treatment.

Diagnosis of orchitis
Diagnosis of orchitis begins with the collection of clinical signs that the patient presents. In addition, the doctor will also need the patient to provide medical history information and risks that can lead to orchitis such as mumps vaccination history and urinary health status. (4)
Next, the doctor will review the condition of the patient's testicles to check for lymph nodes and abnormal secretions from the penis. If there is an epidemic, the doctor will take a sample of the fluid to test for sexually transmitted diseases (STDs).
Other paraclinical diagnostic activities that the doctor will ask the patient to perform depending on each individual's medical condition include:
Diagnosis of rectal conditions and risk of prostate enlargement; Blood tests to diagnose STDs and other infectious diseases; Urine test; Testicular ultrasound to observe the patient's urinary structures including the testicles, surrounding tissues and in the scrotum

Methods of treating orchitis
Orchitis is treated by inhibiting the growth of pathogenic bacteria and relieving the symptoms the patient is experiencing. Most are medical treatment with oral medications.
For people with orchitis due to sexually transmitted infections, the doctor will prescribe a treatment regimen for these STDs before treating orchitis.
Patients are asked to rest in bed and limit activities that may affect the testicles. This creates conditions for the testicles to recover optimally. Besides, based on each symptom, medical history and physical condition of the patient, the doctor will prescribe appropriate medications.
Patients will be treated for orchitis with the following methods:
Use antibiotics if there are signs of infection, gonorrhea or syphilis; Use anti-inflammatory and pain relievers. These medications require the patient to strictly follow the dosage instructions from the doctor. Because if not used properly or overuse of anti-inflammatory drugs, patients will easily develop stomach ulcers; Patients need to rest and elevate their testicles to relieve pain; If the pain is severe, the patient can apply a cold compress to the testicles

Measures to prevent orchitis
Orchitis can be optimally prevented with daily living habits. To minimize the risk of infection, especially urinary tract infections, living environments and bathroom areas need to be kept hygienic to reduce the risk of infection.
In addition, using safe measures when having sex is an important factor to help protect your health. Using condoms not only helps reduce the risk of orchitis but also helps men and their partners minimize other sexually transmitted diseases.
Optimal measures to prevent orchitis:
Carry out mumps vaccination; Practice all safe sex measures to avoid the risk of STDs; Maintain clean living environment and build clean and hygienic living habits; Boys reach the age when they need to be circumcised at the right time; Reduce the number of sexual partners; Treat orchitis early in the acute stage and limit recurrence to avoid the risk of chronic orchitis

Orchitis is a common urinary disease in men. The disease can occur in all subjects and ages. However, people who are or have just recovered from mumps and have sexually transmitted diseases are at higher risk of orchitis than others.
The disease rarely affects fertility in men. However, if the disease is not treated promptly, the patient will face other complications, which can affect urinary health, testicular function and fertility.
subsections.subsection_string:
Measures to prevent orchitis
Orchitis can be optimally prevented with daily living habits. To minimize the risk of infection, especially urinary tract infections, living environments and bathroom areas need to be kept hygienic to reduce the risk of infection.
In addition, using safe measures when having sex is an important factor to help protect your health. Using condoms not only helps reduce the risk of orchitis but also helps men and their partners minimize other sexually transmitted diseases.
Optimal measures to prevent orchitis:
Carry out mumps vaccination; Practice all safe sex measures to avoid the risk of STDs; Maintain clean living environment and build clean and hygienic living habits; Boys reach the age when they need to be circumcised at the right time; Reduce the number of sexual partners; Treat orchitis early in the acute stage and limit recurrence to avoid the risk of chronic orchitis
